_comment: Interpreted: An interpreted language is a programming language for which most of its implementations execute instructions directly, without previously compiling a program into machine-language instructions. The interpreter executes the program directly, translating each statement into a sequence of one or more subroutines already compiled into machine code. (Wikipedia)
name: APL

_comment: Functional Functional programming languages define every computation as a mathematical evaluation. They focus on the application of functions. Many of the functional programming languages are bound to mathematical calculations.
name: Charity

_comment: Compiled A compiled language is a programming language whose implementations are typically compilers (translators that generate machine code from source code), and not interpreters (step-by-step executors of source code, where no pre-runtime translation takes place). (Wikipedia)
name: Ada

_comment: Procedural A compiled language is a programming language whose implementations are typically compilers (translators that generate machine code from source code), and not interpreters (step-by-step executors of source code, where no pre-runtime translation takes place). (Wikipedia)
name: Bliss

_comment: # Markup Languages A markup language is an artificial language that uses annotations to text that define how the text is to be displayed.
name: SGML

_comment: Logic-based Programming Languages Logic programming is a type of programming paradigm which is largely based on formal logic. Any program written in a logic programming language is a set of sentences in logical form, expressing facts and rules about some problem domain. (Wikipedia)
name: ALF

_comment: Concurrent Programming Languages Concurrent programming is a computer programming technique that provides for the execution of operations concurrently — either within a single computer, or across a number of systems.In the latter case, the term distributed computing is used.(Wikipedia)
name: ABCL

_comment: Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on the concept of “objects”, which may contain data, in the form of fields, often known as attributes; and code, in the form of procedures, often known as methods. In OOP, computer programs are designed by making them out of objects that interact with one another. (Wikipedia)
name: Agora
